Certainly. This is the first time Canada has developed infrastructure for a fifth-generation capability. It's highly complex for some of the reasons that we've already covered. We've learned a heck of a lot, actually, as part of this design process. We've been working very closely with EllisDon, the contractor. Through the design predecision, we learned a lot of lessons that we applied in the design post decision, as we made the adjustments to the new requirements.
We are in kind of a constant learning mode on this. We will be applying those lessons very much in the context of future acquisitions, for sure.
That's great.

Do you think there would be an opportunity to actually codify that knowledge and capture it? Anecdotally, it's something that you may talk about in the future, but is there a process where you would turn that into a best practice that's actually documented in a manual or something like that?
I don't know about a manual per se, but my team actively documents lessons learned, to be able to apply these next time.

Infrastructure is often a step or two behind, simply because we build to the requirements of the equipment that is being procured, so we're always looking for ways to keep pace with equipment acquisition to ensure that infrastructure is there in time. These are exactly the types of lessons we learn, document and build into the work we do going forward.
That's good to hear.
I'll go to a very broad question with respect to methodologies and research.
This has obviously been a very extensive overview of a major defence procurement process. We talked about equipment, the storage and the training.
This will be for the Attorney Gen—
I just made you a lawyer. Congratulations.
This will be for the Auditor General.
What types of research methodologies went into your report?
I'm sure many of the lawyers who work for me would be happy if I were a lawyer, but no.

When you talk about research for a comparison or what we do for audits, it would be different. We definitely have data scientists who help support us when we do sampling and stratifying of populations. Here, we would have been looking for some advice of a technical nature.
Not to put Nick on the spot, but he has audited National Defence for decades now, so he does understand them a lot.

We typically try to compare, when we can, to foreign countries. It's a little more difficult in this space, for sure. We do definitely pay attention to what the Government Accountability Office has been doing. They have lots of work on fighter jets and have been talking about increasing costs just coming out of this in general for the F-35.

It's a very broad question. It would depend on the topic. If it were in the health field, I could tell you that we'd go seek out experts there if we didn't necessarily have them. We have the ability to go get what we don't believe we have in-house, and then we do rely on the experts, whom we actually audit. We don't take for granted that they do this day-to-day and they know, but we take a step back for an independent, unbiased view of things.
You are out of time, but if you have a brief follow-up question, please go ahead, Ms. Tesser Derksen.

In this particular instance, did you sense there were gaps in the information you had before you to make reasonable determinations in your reports, or were you pretty satisfied with the data that you were able to access?

We didn't have any access issues here whatsoever. We had the required security clearance to have the conversations and to look at the information that we looked at. I wouldn't say there was an issue here whatsoever on this file.
Thank you very much.

We're going to have a truncated last round, which will give three members various times. Again, to give the government the last slot, I'm going to mix it up. I'm going to have Monsieur Deltell and Monsieur Lemire go first, and then Mr. Osborne will end it for us this afternoon.
Mr. Deltell, you have the floor for five minutes.
Thank you very much, Mr. Chair.

Ms. Beck, I'd like to continue the discussion we had with Mr. Kuruc a few moments ago. You said that, in the woes of war, technological advances are rapid. History has taught us that. We're a long way from the days of Billy Bishop. It's important to remember that at the beginning of the Second World War, biplanes were still used and that the war ended with Messerschmitt 262s. Things changed rapidly.

Without going into the details and revealing any national security information, can you tell us whether the Canadian Armed Forces or the Royal Canadian Air Force have drones? What's the current situation regarding drones? What types of drones do you have?
In fact, we have them for the navy, army and air force. Their nature depends on the needs we have to meet and the results we want to achieve. A lot of research is being done into what else exists.
Where are they made?

They are manufactured all across Canada, including Quebec, Ontario and Alberta. Every day, we receive messages from various Canadian companies that want to offer us products that can help us, especially drones.
Let's continue the discussion and explore this area.

Is that part of the expansion plans for the armed forces and the Royal Canadian Air Force? How much of the budget will be allocated to that? Should we be putting more money into those aircraft, if we can define them that way, rather than into other aircraft?

Absolutely. Investments will be announced not only for the Royal Canadian Air Force, but also for other divisions of the forces. It depends on the need to be met. There are drones that can carry heavy cargoes over long distances, while others are used to deliver things in close proximity very quickly.

Actually, there is one more thing. We will, later this month or in November, have a drone exercise in urban Ottawa, so you will be able to see them. We'll give you warning, and, of course, Transport Canada is aware. This will be a test of all kinds of drones in downtown Ottawa, to see what there might be that we might need to purchase.

Beyond that, we are doing research and inviting other countries to come and show us what they have in terms of all the different kinds of drones, and we also do research in Halifax Harbour, on underwater drones.
I don't need to tell you that we're very interested in what comes next, particularly because, in our opinion, it must be done here in Canada.
There's a lot of expertise.
We have a golden opportunity to develop expertise, and we know that we have very good expertise in this area.

Before concluding, I'd like to come back to a very important point raised in Ms. Hogan's report, namely the shortage of qualified pilots. That was the case in 2018, and it's still true six years later.

Lieutenant-General, do you think we're technically ready? Ms. Hogan mentioned that, when the planes are ready, it's still not entirely certain that there will be enough pilots. What's your reading of the situation?
Thank you for the question.

That's something we're working on very deliberately. We're making changes to training, and planning to replace our training fleets so that we can train more pilots. We're expanding. Indeed, since 2018, we've seen that a number of our initiatives have helped to increase the number of pilots. We're talking about recruiting more pilots, but also about implementing initiatives to retain experienced people, which is very important. This will involve continuing to implement our plans as well as continuing to assess and verify conditions annually.

When we set up our F‑35 personnel, we'll be able to judge how operational we are based on the number of people we have. Right now, we're optimistic about rebuilding our workforce. To what extent will that be done? I'll have to continue working on that. We also work with maintenance people.

We've also heard that there will be a need to expand the support capacity, so intelligence and planning for missions, as well as the security forces, which we talked about. So there are a number of areas where we're increasing our strength, and the fairly recent announcement of investment in defence and the Canadian Armed Forces allows us to make plans for growth.
Thank you very much.
Mr. Lemire, you have the floor for two and a half minutes.
Thank you, Mr. Chair.

Ms. Beck, I'd like to quickly talk about the Bagotville military base. In January 2023, during an interview with the Kick FM radio station, former minister of national defence Anita Anand estimated that the work in Bagotville would cost $500 million. However, the work was launched on August 12, 2024, with an investment of only $120 million.
How do you explain this discrepancy?
This is just the beginning of the project, that's all. There's nothing extraordinary about that. We don't pay for everything the first year, of course. We pay as we go.
Mr. Hammerschmidt could add some details, because this is a complex project.
Since we know that there will be delays, why did the government not accelerate investments at the outset?

To date, we've spent $125 million on the Bagotville military base. We've committed $319 million to develop the temporary rapid response area in Bagotville, and we're also beginning construction on facilities for the future fighter fleet.
On another note, National Defence will have to defend the north. Obviously, the sovereignty of the Arctic is a very important issue, and we have to show our presence.

Since we won't necessarily be able to store all the equipment in one place, we'd have to find a place that experiences winter conditions. The region I represent, Abitibi-Témiscamingue, has a strategic position for that, in addition to having many mining companies.

In a context where National Defence must increase its investments, but also improve its recruitment, training, or conduct rescue operations, I believe that Abitibi-Témiscamingue has an important role to play.
How could regions like mine contribute more to National Defence?
We're always pleased to have much more assistance in the regions, especially in the north. We're in the process of looking at different locations for operational support hubs in the north.
We've chosen Iqaluit, Inuvik and Yellowknife to host those hubs, and we're looking for two more cities that will unfortunately be farther north than Abitibi-Témiscamingue.
Interoperability is nevertheless important, and we need to have places where we can pass a trans-Canada highway and rail tracks, to supply the north. I'm telling you that in passing.
We'll keep that in mind.
All right.
Thank you, Mr. Chair.
Thank you very much.
Mr. Osborne, you'll take us out for five minutes, please.
Thank you, Mr. Chair.
I guess this is for the deputy.

The Auditor General found that National Defence was more reactive than proactive in terms of risk management. Effective planning and risk management are paramount, especially as we see the geopolitical...and the risks.
Can you talk about the improvements you've put in place so that you become more proactive?

I think the Auditor General is exactly right. The department has traditionally been very risk-averse and very controlled in decision-making and in purposeful spending. That is largely because of the constraints around the operating capabilities of the department in terms of resources. There are not enough people and there is not enough money.

This has changed. With that, it has become necessary to shift significantly how we evaluate and manage risk, and then how we mitigate what the different risks are. Layered on top of that is what you mentioned: The geopolitical situation has changed. We are in a different world from the one we were in even three or four years ago, or prepandemic.

This has meant an entire shift in the whole conversation in the department—with the military as well as with civilians. I would even go so far as to add our colleagues around town, because we have to take a completely different lens to the future of the Department of National Defence and of the CAF now, with funding that we can see coming for decades at a much higher level than was the case before.

We are going to be relying not only on our existing partners. For instance, the creation of the new Defence Investment Agency is going to help us manage that risk. It's going to help us deliver projects and programs much faster than has been the case to date.
Thank you. You led perfectly into my next question.

This is probably more for the lieutenant-general. The commitment of the Prime Minister and of Canada to meet NATO spending targets of 2%, 3.5% and 5% presents tremendous opportunity and excitement, I would say, for you. At the same time, the risks to our sovereignty and the tensions globally create additional challenges.

Looking at the national defence industrial strategy, for example, can we talk about what that means for Canada's economy and for Canada's workforce? What are the benefits to Canada and to our forces with the increased spending?
What does the future look like?
I'll pass it over to you in a second.

The defence industrial strategy is in the definition phase right now, to use a military term. We've spoken with over 1,000 people. We've had input from all across the country and have deliberately sought out the views of provinces, territories and first nations communities. We're gathering all that together.

The goal of the strategy will be to increase investment in the defence industry to enable that to happen, with the support not only of the government but of the private sector as well. It's to make sure that the end result is our sovereign capabilities—we were talking about drones earlier—and access to capabilities that we will always need, that we can find at home and that we'll be able to rely on in the future.
We're doing that, of course, in close collaboration with the military, to make sure what we're targeting as sovereign capabilities are the ones they need not just now but in the future as well.
Thank you.
I would just maybe add three points that would summarize my view of the way you framed that.

It is an amazing opportunity. We're very grateful for the increased investment. The RCAF has been on a path of modernization. It's the biggest one since the Second World War. We are creating the air and space force that Canada needs, not just now but for decades to come.

With this increased investment, certainly the opportunities to work differently with industry are there. I believe there's a tremendous prospect there. It's also allowing us to fix some of the foundations, because, frankly, there has been a lack of investment over several decades. Infrastructure has been a focus. Digital transformation is a focus. Those are going to allow us to then modernize more effectively.

It's really key, as mentioned, about the risk approach. How we do this is going to be very important. As you mentioned, it is a positive opportunity, but it is also quite challenging. It's important that we spend the money and the investments judiciously, ensure that we have continued value for money, and show and reassure Canadians that this is happening in a positive manner for the sovereignty and safety of Canadians.
Thank you.
If you have a quick follow-up, go ahead, please.

I have one quick follow-up. I know that in addition to Bagotville and Cold Lake, there are several other fighter locations across the country. I know each region is hoping for upgrades and investments, especially as we look at the F-35.
Can you give us some indication of what that would look like for the other locations throughout the country?

Certainly, from an infrastructure perspective, there is a lot of focus on Bagotville and Cold Lake. However, as you have mentioned, they are not the only parts of the country. In terms of all of the forward operating locations, we have three of them in the north. Those will be upgraded to a whole range of infrastructure initiatives, including airfield rehabilitation, power grid modernization, runway work and facilities work.

There are also the deployed operating bases that are across the country. I'm going to miss one, I think, but they include Greenwood, Comox, Goose Bay, Winnipeg and Trenton. Those will all receive upgrades, as well.

Beyond that, we have three command centres, in Winnipeg, Ottawa and North Bay. Those too will receive upgrades, particularly for command and control to be able to operate the fighters and other aircraft.

On that day, instead of meeting in the afternoon, we will be meeting as Parliament opens, at 10 a.m. We will be meeting with the Auditor General to get her public comments on the report right away. This is standard for this, and it has been approved by the various whips for that to happen.
Without further ado, I'll excuse the witnesses. Thank you very much.
